word.entryDescription: not interesting
word.entryExample: I think baseball is boring.

word.entryDescription: to take and use something that does not belong to you, which you have to give back later
word.entryExample: My friend told me I could borrow her CD of the soundtrack.

word.entryDescription: always telling people what to do
word.entryExample: Mrs Sharp is always angry, bossy and impatient when dealing with other people.

word.entryDescription: a person who makes scientific studies of plants
word.entryExample: Ecologists, botanists, biologists and other scientists know that destroying complex rainforest ecosystems has a huge negative impact on the world.

word.entryDescription: a narrow container we put liquid in, usually made of glass or plastic
word.entryExample: Lucy bought a bottle of milk for the cat.

word.entryDescription: a container in the street where people can leave their empty bottles to make it possible for the glass to be recycled
word.entryExample: You can't put dirty bottles with metal tops in this bottle bank.

word.entryDescription: the lowest part of something
word.entryExample: The cat is sitting at the bottom of the stairs.

word.entryDescription: to move up and down with small movements
word.entryExample: On the way to the island the plane bounced a lot and I was afraid.

word.entryDescription: a knot with two loops and two loose ends used as a decoration on clothes, hair, etc
word.entryExample: Bows, ties and sashes are considered finishing touches.

word.entryDescription: a weapon used for shooting arrows made of a long curved piece of wood with a tight string attached to its ends
word.entryExample: He's holding a bow in his left hand and an arrow in his right hand.

word.entryDescription: a man's tie that is tied in the shape of a bow, worn around the neck
word.entryExample: The designer is looking very smart in a black dinner jacket and red bow tie.

word.entryDescription: a plate with high sides used to hold food or liquids
word.entryExample: I had a bowl of soup for lunch.

word.entryDescription: a player in cricket whose job is to throw the ball towards batsman
word.entryExample: The bowler tries to hit the wicket.

word.entryDescription: a game in which you roll a bowl down a wooden track to knock over some bottle-shaped wooden objects
word.entryExample: You could go bowling together.

word.entryDescription: a square or rectangular container you use to store things in
word.entryExample: Can I have a box of chocolates, please?

word.entryDescription: a band or chain worn around the wrist or arm as decoration
word.entryExample: I want to buy a friendship bracelet for Anika and send it to her.

word.entryDescription: the organ which thinks and controls the body
word.entryExample: The cells send signals to the brain about our movements.

word.entryDescription: very clever, able to learn quickly
word.entryExample: Mary was always the brainy one.

word.entryDescription: plural of 'branch' – a part of a tree that grows out of the trunk and has leaves or fruit growing on it
word.entryExample: The stilts are made of wood that used to be the branches of a tree.

word.entryDescription: a product made by a particular company, often with a recognisable name, design or symbol
word.entryExample: People often use clothes and clothing brands instead of the class system to present their economic and social position.

word.entryDescription: a food made from flour and water and baked in the oven
word.entryExample: I usually eat bread and jam for breakfast.

word.entryDescription: (past simple form: 'broke', past participle 'broken') to damage something by making it come apart, or by stopping it from working
word.entryExample: Finally, he looked at my leg. He said that he thought it was broken.

word.entryDescription: (of a vehicle or machine) to stop working due to a mechanical problem
word.entryExample: The taxi broke down on the way to the airport.

word.entryDescription: to enter a building illegally and by force
word.entryExample: They were trying to break in but luckily the police patrol noticed it and arrested them.

word.entryDescription: the food you eat in the morning
word.entryExample: I have breakfast after I get up.

word.entryDescription: the process of moving air into and out of your lungs
word.entryExample: All relaxation techniques combine deep breathing with relaxing the muscles.

word.entryDescription: a light wind
word.entryExample: There's going to be a light breeze by the sea.

word.entryDescription: a structure which you can use to cross over a road or river
word.entryExample: This is one of the most famous bridges in Venice.

word.entryDescription: for a short time
word.entryExample: He was briefly suspected of being involved in the crime, but he wasn't arrested because he had an alibi.

word.entryDescription: full of light
word.entryExample: The doctor's surgery where I went was very bright and clean.

word.entryDescription: extremely clever
word.entryExample: That's brilliant, Lucy!

word.entryDescription: to take something to or towards the place where you are
word.entryExample: I want to bring Kim a present.

word.entryDescription: to take care of a child and influence their development as they grow up
word.entryExample: Emma was brought up by her parents in London.

word.entryDescription: injured, damaged or no longer functioning
word.entryExample: I can't run, because my leg is broken.

word.entryDescription: a man or boy who has the same parents as you
word.entryExample: This is my brother Eddie.

word.entryDescription: something that is brown is the colour of the earth or chocolate
word.entryExample: I'm wearing a brown hat.

word.entryDescription: a dark mark caused by bleeding under the skin, often the result of being hit
word.entryExample: Axel's bruise was black and blue.

word.entryDescription: to clean your teeth
word.entryExample: Sam must brush his teeth before he goes to bed.

word.entryDescription: a very small animal with lots of legs that often lives on the ground
word.entryExample: Look at these bugs – they're so big!

word.entryDescription: a structure which normally has walls and a roof
word.entryExample: Big Ben is older than many buildings in New York.

word.entryDescription: being rounded and sticking out, often by being full of something
word.entryExample: Santa arrived, his bag bulging with presents.

word.entryDescription: an emotional disorder in which a person repeatedly eats too much and then forces oneself to vomit to control their weight
word.entryExample: Bulimia damages health and can be life-threatening.

word.entryDescription: a house without an upstairs level
word.entryExample: My granddad lives in a bungalow because it's difficult for him to walk up stairs.

word.entryDescription: minced meat made into a flat shape and cooked
word.entryExample: I had a burger and chips for lunch.

word.entryDescription: somebody who tries secretly to enter a building in order to steal things
word.entryExample: The burglar managed to escape through the back door without being seen.

word.entryDescription: the crime of entering a building in a secret manner in order to steal things
word.entryExample: They arrested her last week and she was charged with burglary.

word.entryDescription: an injury caused by heat, fire, electricity, chemicals, etc
word.entryExample: Oooh, the burn's made a nasty blister.

word.entryDescription: to suddenly and quickly move somewhere
word.entryExample: When rivers burst their banks there are few defenses against floodwater.

word.entryDescription: to suddenly and noisily enter a room or building
word.entryExample: Donnie Register was working in his shop one afternoon when two thieves burst in and demanded money, pointing a gun at him.

word.entryDescription: a person who drives a bus
word.entryExample: Mr Park works as a bus driver.
